title: Replace Newtonsoft.Json with System.Text.Json in APIView

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

body:
Consolidates JSON serialization to use only `System.Text.Json` across the APIView codebase, removing the Newtonsoft.Json dependency as requested.

## Changes

### Model attributes
- Removed duplicate converter attributes where both libraries were specified
- Migrated annotations: `[JsonProperty]` â†’ `[JsonPropertyName]`, `StringEnumConverter` â†’ `JsonStringEnumConverter`
- Updated null handling: `NullValueHandling.Ignore` â†’ `JsonIgnore(Condition = JsonIgnoreCondition.WhenWritingNull)`

### Serialization calls
- `JsonConvert.SerializeObject/DeserializeObject` â†’ `JsonSerializer.Serialize/Deserialize`
- `JArray.Parse()` â†’ `JsonDocument.Parse()` with `EnumerateArray()`
- `JObject` dynamic indexing â†’ `JsonNode` with `GetValue<T>()`

### Package
- Removed `Newtonsoft.Json` from `APIViewWeb.csproj`

## Example

**Before:**
```csharp
var users = JsonConvert.DeserializeObject<GithubUser[]>(body);
var orgs = JArray.Parse(await response.Content.ReadAsStringAsync());
foreach (var org in orgs) {
    orgNames.Append(org["login"]);
}
```

**After:**
```csharp
var users = JsonSerializer.Deserialize<GithubUser[]>(body);
using var orgsDoc = JsonDocument.Parse(await response.Content.ReadAsStringAsync());
foreach (var org in orgsDoc.RootElement.EnumerateArray()) {
    if (org.TryGetProperty("login", out var loginProperty)) {
        orgNames.Append(loginProperty.GetString());
    }
}
```

## Impact
17 files changed. All existing tests pass. No API contract changes.

title: C++ APIView - The type `PathSetAccessControlRecursiveMode` isn't showing up which comes from the protocol header file.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: This issue requires a change to an existing behavior in the product in order to be resolved.

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: C++
labels.description: C++ Language

body:
From https://apiview.dev/Assemblies/Review/427b38f4cc7d41b49159ede265ef5cce#Azure::Storage::Files::DataLake::DirectoryClient

Things from the protocol layer aren't showing up in the APIView. For example:
`PathSetAccessControlRecursiveMode`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6527137/98583068-aaafcd00-2278-11eb-9207-f32620fa9d84.png)

Steps to generate:
```text
clang++ .\sdk\storage\azure-storage-files-datalake\inc\azure\storage\files\datalake.hpp -I .\sdk\storage\azure-storage-files-datalake\inc -I .\sdk\core\azure-core\inc -I .\sdk\storage\azure-storage-common\inc  -I .\sdk\storage\azure-storage-blobs\inc -I .\sdk\identity\azure-identity\inc -Xclang -ast-dump > az_datalake.ast

Archive the file Compress-Archive az_datalake.ast -DestinationPath az_datalake.zip
Rename the file Rename-Item az_datalake.zip -NewName az_datalake.cppast
Upload the resulting archive.
```

This enum is defined in the protocol layer which the client APIs take a dependency on:
https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-cpp/blob/a7672f67f6fbc7db1a81666e0cf2370625572b2e/sdk/storage/azure-storage-files-datalake/inc/azure/storage/files/datalake/protocol/datalake_rest_client.hpp#L127-L133
https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-cpp/blob/6bb5cd788cd8f7e034a9fc65b121d7963ee07e48/sdk/storage/azure-storage-files-datalake/inc/azure/storage/files/datalake/datalake_directory_client.hpp#L13

**This header isn't explicitly included when generating the APIView since other headers include them. Does it need to be?**

cc @praveenkuttappan, @RickWinter

title: [APIView] Support Forcing APIView Revision in More Scenarios

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
While reviewing the Java Core API views this month I noticed that many of the API views haven't been updated for a few weeks. From discussions with @praveenkuttappan I was informed that a new API view will only be generated if a meaningful difference has been made. At least for Java, changing dependency versions isn't a meaningful difference (one that'll require approval before releasing) and for many libraries that will be the only difference that may occur for months. Unfortunately, this means useful information may be lost and could result in confusing API views to exist. For example [azure-core-serializer-json-jackson](https://apiview.dev/Assemblies/Review/83768c0e56094634b973c8de003c09de/7702690237e743cdb7134c4534280611?diffRevisionId=b9f6537c29444b88900bb3b1ef76c64c&doc=False&diffOnly=True) looks like it has had a recent API difference but looking at API view metadata and knowing the library it has been API stable for a few months, only receiving dependency updates.

My request is that API view should support more granular updating, instead of checking for a meaningful difference to update the latest API view it should be any difference in what is generated. So, for Java this would mean that upgrading dependencies would cause a new API view, to give reviewers the most up-to-date information as possible.

title: [APIView] Diagnostics - add suppressed status

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
On Python, we are moving toward making APIView diagnostics potentially build failing issues or issues that prevent approval. To facilitate that, I'm working on a mechanism to suppress APIView errors on a case-by-case basis via code syntax (a la pylint). However, in the APIView web tool, it would be very useful if the diagnostic object had a property that could be set.

The model already supports four levels of diagnostics: Default, Info, Warning, Error.

This could either be a boolean property or another status. Having a boolean property would retain the character of the diagnostic while maintaining that it is suppressed, whereas simply have a "Suppressed" status would lose the character of the original diagnostic. For those reasons, I would recommend a boolean.

Suppressions would be handled in code, so there would be no web-side work except how they are displayed and supporting the new property in the model. 

A suppressed diagnostic would still display in the UI, but it would be muted or changed visually so reviewers would know that this is suppressed.

title: Python wheels submitted as `revisions` are not being updated to associate with original target package after sandboxed processing

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

body: If go to `APIView`, open an active package (this occurred on `azure-search-documents`), and then add a new revision from a wheel file, we do two things. 1. Add a temporary review named for the wheel file as we haven't yet processed the file 2. Kick off processing of the uploaded wheel artifact, which runs in a separate environment. Unfortunately, what's happening when the sandboxed processing completes, is that when it posts back to `APIView` with the parsed stub information, it posts back _to the original placeholder review_, instead of the real target package. This means that we end up with a bunch of placeholders around, but our manually uploaded wheel never re-associates with the original target package we attempted to add a revision to: Image for example: Each of these was a manually submitted wheel that was then never associated properly. We should: - [ ] Identify sandboxed runs like this - [ ] Parse the package name while processing the stub - [ ] find the review associated with package name, associate revision with that target - [ ] Clean up old placeholder review

title: [APIView] Convert Diagnostics to Comments

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: APIView Copilot
labels.description: Issues related to APIView Copilot

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
When the comment update is complete, comments will have a severity value. We need to expose a process that ensures that any diagnostics are exposed as comments.

- Diagnostic comments should be exposed as being posted by "azure-sdk", the same as AI comments.
- Diagnostic severities need to be mapped to comment severities
  - Must Fix: Fatal and Error
  - Should Fix: Warning
  - Suggestion: Info
- The text of the diagnostics and the help link and so on should be placed as the body of the Diagnostic Comment.
- Diagnostic comments should be un-editable, same as AI comments.
- Diagnostic comments should be flagged, at least internally, that they are from diagnostics and not AI. We probably _should_ provide a visual hint in APIView as well. 

Ideally, we should not change the schema for Diagnostics sent in the CodeFile, but we can if there's a compelling reason.

labels.name: APIView

body:
With swagger/Cadl support coming online for APIView, I feel one important feature that's needed is to somehow block PRs on GitHub from being merged while there are unresolved comments. Ideally, showing those comments on appropriate lines in the PR would be nice so we're not forced to use separate tools- GitHub and APIView - but perhaps consider that a stretch or I can open another issue.

At the very least, perhaps some sort of hook to prevent merging while there are unresolved comments. I assume links will still be added to PRs so that service teams know to look at APIView, but randomized assignees for merging need to know why a PR is blocked and not be able to override e.g., a required check.

title: [APIView] Add support for commenting on multiple lines of API

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
In GitHub, it is possible to leave a comment that applies to multiple lines in a PR, by clicking the mouse where a single comment would be added, and then dragging it over multiple lines. As you drag, a blue line (and a different background colour) indicate where the comment would be applied to:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1427840/220751462-75877c8d-e587-43c9-be31-0ae0e118cefc.png)

Upon releasing the mouse, you are presented with a comment box like usual, with an indicator again showing the lines that are being commented on (circled in red in the picture below):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1427840/220751653-fdbc7098-e14c-44e0-be9c-86f1f6506077.png)

I often find that I would like to do the same in APIView, where my comment doesn't apply directly to a single line, but rather a whole class or a group of APIs, and it would be nice to indicate to the person receiving the comment that this is the case. As part of this work, it may be necessary to improve how a comment in an APIView is related to an API - at present you can just assume that a comment relates to the line directly above it, but this would no longer be sufficient if it could relate to multiple lines.

title: [APIView] Feature request: colored text

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: This issue requires a new behavior in the product in order be resolved.

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
I would like the ability to have a custom color for text tokens in APIView.

Here are two use cases:

### Unrecognized syntax in source

The current color is black. However, I'm working on making Swift APIView more resilient to changes in the Swift languages. That will involve rendering syntax that the current code doesn't recognize (for example, Apple adds an entirely new concept to the language). The new version will handle this, rending the unknown thing with text tokens. While it may lack some functionality (i.e. may not be clickable or commentable) it will at least appear (whereas today the tool will just crash).

I would very much like to render these "fallback text" tokens in red so that I can easily see looking at the APIView that something is wonky.

### Concepts not modeled in APIView today

Cadl has aliases, and we render those in APIView to remain source-accurate and allow architects to see what those aliases actually mean. Right now, we are constrained to display them as type references, but would like the ability to display them differently so that the architects know visually that this is an alias and will not actually find its way into generated code.

The simplest option would be to have a different color for these, but it doesn't fit the existing APIView token types. Color customization would be the simplest way to achieve this.

body:
I showed @KrzysztofCwalina the picture below, and he asked "When can we ship this in the APIView tool?"

The idea behind this is to encode information in a visual UI affordance that provides an at-a-glance view of the work remaining on a given API before we would expect it to GA.  This helps answer questions for architects and library authors including:
- Could I ship this today? (i.e. are there ship-blockers here?)
- How much work remains to get this API to the state where we'd be happy shipping it?

It would be super cool to have this in the APIView tool to help us understand and track remaining work?

title: Swagger API - Readme tag is read incorrectly

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: Central-EngSys
labels.description: This issue is owned by the Engineering System team.

body:
Swagger API uses the tag in readme to generate API review for modified files. If tag is in data format without any string prefix or suffix then tag is auto converted to date string in ISO format, and this causes API review step to fail. We need to pass original schema param to YAML library to avoid this auto conversion of string literal to date object.

For e.g., tag in README is `2024-04-01` but this got converted to `2024-04-01T00:00:00.000Z` when YAML package processes this README.

title: APIView - Do not remove automatic revision if revision is for a different package version

labels.name: bug
labels.description: This issue requires a change to an existing behavior in the product in order to be resolved.

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

body:
CI build automatic revision every day and APIView deletes latest pending revision when a new request is processed to create automatic revision that has API changes. We should remove automatic revision only if it is for same package version to avoid removing an automatic version (in pending status) that was created for a different package version.

Context: Go azcore had version 1.17.0 in pending status and they released a hotfix which removed the revision for 1.17.0 even though it's for a different package version. This causes issue in API change detection in PR when all further PR is compared against latest automatic revision created for hotfix instead of comparing against latest main branch revision.

title: [Namespace Approval] Management Plane Namespace Approval Process

labels.name: APIView

body:
TypeSpec API review:

- [x] Add a button to request namespace approval in TypeSpec API review if TypeSpec review has related API revisions for SDK languages.
- [x] When a user clicks on this button, it should identify related API view request for each language and mark them as "Namespace approval requested". We need to adda new flag in DB at review level to support it.
- [x] When all the associated languages namespace approved, request namespace approval button would become Namespace approved.
- [x] APIView server should also send an email to all approvers when a namespace review is requested. Email template should include all languages API links, recipients including users

APIView:
- [x]  Add a new pending namespace approval tab that shows all pending requested namespace approval(based on the flag).
- [x] Page should also a show an option "Show all reviews without namespace approval" as filter.
- [x] If user selects the option to show all reviews without namespace approval, then it should show all the reviews that does not have namespace approval.

CI:
- [x]  We should enable API reviews for management plane for all languages. Currently it is disabled for Python.
- [x]  Currently pipeline checks for APIView and namespace status only for all data plane releases and only .NET management plane release. We need to change this to check ONLY Namespace approval status for the management plane for Java, JS, Python and Go in addition to current logic. It should not check for APIView approval and check for namespace approval only.


[Optional enhancements]
- [ ] We can add an option in release planner to request namespace approval that will send a request the backend API used by APView button to request namespace approval
- [ ] Add similar feature in AI agent

User workflow:
1. User submits spec PR and this creates API reviews.
2. Service partner team request namespace approval from TypeSpec APIView.

title: [APIView] Lightweight App Permissions

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: design-discussion
labels.description: An area of design currently under discussion and open to team and community feedback.

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
Today, APIView has permissions established through configuration options, mostly the "approvers" list, which is self-select.

However, we have UI components today that we would like to show/hide or enable/disable based on the role of the user, but we have no clear, formal means of designating user roles.

I'm proposing some kind of lightweight RBAC system whereby we can designate app permissions to users and/or groups of users and use that consistently to decide what functionality is available to users.

**User Roles**
In order of how permissive each role is
- Service Team
- SDK Team
- Deputy Architect - similar permissions to architect 
- Architect - elevated permissions when only an architect will do
- Admin - highest level permissions, only for APIView maintainers

Roles could be scoped to languages. For example, Johan would be an SDK Team member generally (for all languages) but the Architect for Python. So this would mean Johan could do whatever an SDK Team member could generally do in APIView for any language, but would have Archtect-level permissions for Python. However, we would not be able to use admin-level features for any language.

This would also resolve weird things like how we currently treat anyone in the "approvers" list as an architect, which is sloppy modeling.

title: Auto suggest similar review comments project

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: APIView Copilot
labels.description: Issues related to APIView Copilot

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
Use case: API reviewer reviews API surface using APIView tool and creates a comment on a specific line in the review. Reviewer needs to find and comment on each line which has similar problem within the same review, and this is time consuming if package has multiple namespaces and classes and if the review has thousands of lines. We can utilize AI to auto detect similar issues to help the reviewer in this case.

Goal: Auto detect any similar issues within the review when a reviewer creates a comment. APIView can show a prompt with all suggestions from AI to inform the reviewer and if reviewer agrees then it can apply these auto-detected comments to review.

Process flow:
1. Reviewer creates a comment at a specific line in APIView
2. APIView sends the comment, API text at the commented line and complete API surface to AI to detect similar suggestions.
3. APIView processes the response and send it as a notification prompt to reviewer and this notification will show the  API line and suggestion from AI
4. Reviewer can either selectively apply the suggestion, apply all suggestions or reject all suggestions

It takes around 5- 10 seconds to get a response from AI and depends on the API surface. User is not blocked between 2 and 3 and auto detection runs as async process in the backend and shows a push notification to reviewer  when response is available from AI.

We can add a checkbox in create comment screen that will allow architect to disable this auto detection if they don't want to run

title: [API View] Add E2E Testing to API View

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

body:
As we add more features to API View, manual testing becomes increasingly unreliable due to the growing number of cases to validate.

This applies to both the server (which has unit testing but lacks working E2E tests) and especially the UI.

I want to avoid investing significant time testing every scenario manually, or worse, breaking functionality because a scenario was overlooked.

Adding E2E testing has significant implications and concerns, including flaky tests, authentication challenges, and more.

I'd like to start by narrowing the scope to get E2E tests running locally first, with the eventual goal of running them in CI. For now, we can begin with local execution and make commitments to adding and running these tests consistently.

For example, this issue was reported this week is a clear example of regressions:
- https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/issues/12994

title: [APIView] Cross-Language Feature Design

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: design needed
labels.description: [UX design] This work item needs design input.

labels.name: APIView Copilot
labels.description: Issues related to APIView Copilot

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
A requirement for the archboard revamp process to enable automated reviews and approvals is a way to have a cross-language conversation in APIView.

**This issue is not to track implementation, but to track the need to develop and vet a solution, as this is still very ill-defined.**

We have discussed a couple ways this might manifest, based on the work that has already been done in APIView to enable cross-language IDs.

**Cross-Langauge Conversations Tab**

This would present a unified conversations tab that would include comments (and context snippets) for comments across all languages for a given review, allowing any architect to see the conversations for every other review. In this view, comments could be marked as applicable to one or more languages to identify and resolve cross-language impacts.

This view would allow replies to existing comments, but would not allow the creation of new comments (just like the current conversations tab today)

**Cross-language Review Page**

This would present some common form--likely TypeSpec--where architects could leave feedback and mark that feedback as relevant to one or more languages. This view would show only syntax that has a cross-language ID, and architects would be able to easily see how that concept is rendered in their language.

**Dashboard**

There is some sketch of a cross-language dashboard that would show the "10,000 ft view" for all languages for a given package.

title: Expose APIView functionality to tools/mcp agents

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: APIView Copilot
labels.description: Issues related to APIView Copilot

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
Enable MCP tooling to interact with APIView service so different tools can consume the APIs and take advantage of the functionality APIView offers. 

## Scope - Initial Implementation

During this initial effort, the expectation is to establish how future integrations for API View will happen and expose the following tooling:

- **API Comments**:  Get comments from API package
- **API Content**: Retrieve the content of APIs 

### MCP Tools (for conversational AI/LLM integration and CLI access)
- **`apiview package comments`**: Retrieve comments for a specific APIView revision

Support for multiple input methods: revision/review id, APIView URL, or package name with language
```
apiview package comments --package-name <name> --language <language>
apiview package comments --url <url>
apiview package comments --review-id or --revision-id
```

### CLI Commands (for command-line access only)
- **`apiview package content`**: Get comments for revisions with filtering options

Support for multiple input methods: revision ID, APIView URL, or package name
```
apiview package content --package-name <name> --language
apiview package content --url <url>
apiview package content --review-id or --revision-id
```

## Related Issues
- #11015 - [APIView] Provide API to request diff of two versions 
- #11062 - [APIView Copilot] MCP Support

title: [API View] Automatically Clean Up Stale Comments in API View

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

body:
There is an accumulation of stale comments in API View, especially after a library reaches General Availability (GA). These comments are often no longer relevant or actionable, as API design issues are difficult to address post-GA. 

There are two aspects on this problem:
- new comments
- existing comments 

## New comments 
The proposal is to implement a mechanism that auto-resolves or removes non-must-fix comments when a library goes GA, while providing a way to retain or track important design discussions separately (e.g., via a special label or by opening GitHub issues for future consideration).

## Existing comments
The problem is how are we going to clean up the existing stale comments, what is a good rule to delete the existing comments? can we delete the comments that specific to revision that are related to a GA release version?

I tried to get information about how many comments are in this place, but the number is not accurate but is on the thousand, around 4,000, and there are revisions heavily impacted like [Azure.ResourceManager.ApiManagement](https://spa.apiview.dev/review/441201e06d7e48a895102a33026828c0?activeApiRevisionId=58e3c37356fe47edbaeecf2c8c68b3fd) with 253 comment, or [Azure.ResourceManager.Storage](https://spa.apiview.dev/review/552ab789297f4327bd68aed12c6db2ff?activeApiRevisionId=b5d1e2abb8bc4615bbd36af368dcaf88) with 167 comments

## Notes
There are additional considerations in here
 - When API lines are changed (renamed) we need to not loss the comments that was originally tied to the elementId (token Id) - we should investigate if this is still required

title: [API View] Enhance API View Notification Emails with Context for Comment Replies

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

body:
Currently, when a comment is replied to or resolved in API View, the notification emails sent to reviewers lack sufficient context. Reviewers often receive high volumes of emails with minimal information, making it difficult to identify which API or comment the notification refers to. This results in extra effort to locate the relevant thread and verify the resolution. 

Expectations: 
- Notification emails should include the full comment thread and API context.
- Emails should highlight high-severity issues and make them easily identifiable. (After issues have a severity)
- Direct links in emails should reliably take reviewers to the relevant API View item.
- Improved email content will help reviewers quickly assess and act on notifications.

body:
Issue #10789 will result in exposing a new "summarization" endpoint on the Copilot service. APIView will need to shift to using this endpoint in order to improve the UX around summary requests, because the current logic is that Copilot will not regenerate a summary once one has been created.

1. Add metadata key-value pairs to Comment model
2. Expose a new "Generate Summary" button that calls the summary endpoint with `language`, `target` and `base` as request body params.
3. When the response is received, encode that Comment with the revisions ID(s) as metadata
4. Stop sending the summary comment as part of the API Review `comments` request body
5. For a given revision or pair of revisions (diff) only show the summary comment whose metadata matches what is being viewed, if any.
6. If a summary comment is visible, then the "Request Summary" button should not be clickable.

title: [API View] Validate and Enforce No Duplicate Line IDs

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: APIView Copilot
labels.description: Issues related to APIView Copilot

body:
## Summary
While reviewing a code file in API View, I encountered a bug caused by duplicate element IDs in the following revision:
ðŸ”— https://spa.apiview.dev/review/8129e6c762924e02836a2e79b2b480a6?activeApiRevisionId=55c25374ba80457c94d26ddb6d83600e
This issue originated from the Python parser, and it caused the "Generate Copilot Review" flow to fail.

## Problem
- The error is not clearly communicated to users.
- The failure occurs late in the flow, making it harder to debug.
- There is no early validation to catch duplicate line IDs. 

## Proposal
Introduce validation when a code file is created to:
- Detect duplicate line IDs early.
- Display a clear error message that:
  - Identifies the specific duplicate line ID.
  - Helps users understand that the parser needs to be fixed.

title: [APIView] Provide a means to get AD identity or Github identity from the other

labels.name: APIView
labels.description: Issues related to APIView core functionality or UI

labels.name: APIView Copilot
labels.description: Issues related to APIView Copilot

body:
We are able to authenticate to APIView's API using Github auth or AD auth. For apps (like Copilot) it can only communication with AD auth, because it doesn't have a Github account. However, individuals could authenticate using either. Authorization for sensitive operations is controlled via the Github ID, so if a user authenticated with AD, we need a reliable way to retrieve their Github ID.

Here's some info from the Microsoft Open Source channel on how we might do that.

==========

To retrieve linked identities (e.g., AD or GitHub) at Microsoft, you can use the Open Source Management Portal (OSMP). The portal provides interactive tools for searching linked identities based on usernames or employee names. For example, you can navigate to repos.opensource.microsoft.com/people?q=<query> to search for specific identities. Additionally, linked identity data is available in the CloudMine GitHub database (githubemployeelink table) and through an OSMP API.

If you need access to the OSMP API, you can onboard by opening a ticket at [aka.ms/opensource/ticket](https://aka.ms/opensource/ticket). The API documentation is available in the public GitHub repository at [microsoft/opensource-portal](https://github.com/microsoft/opensource-portal/blob/develop/docs/api.md). Authentication is performed using AAD with the resource scope api://2789159d-8d8b-4d13-b90b-ca29c1707afd[[1](https://eng.ms/docs/initiatives/open-source-at-microsoft/github/opensource/incident-response)][[2](https://eng.ms/docs/initiatives/open-source-at-microsoft/tools/insights/index)].

For further assistance or manual operations, you can contact the Open Source Enterprise administrators at github@microsoft.com[[1](https://eng.ms/docs/initiatives/open-source-at-microsoft/github/opensource/incident-response)].

References:
[Incident Response Documentation](https://eng.ms/docs/initiatives/open-source-at-microsoft/github/opensource/incident-response)
[OSMP API Documentation](https://eng.ms/docs/initiatives/open-source-at-microsoft/tools/insights/index)
See Also:  [eng.ms](https://eng.ms/docs/initiatives/open-source-at-microsoft/github/opensource/accounts/linking)
 
 
See also, the data referenced at https://aka.ms/opensource/incident-response covers data options for this.
 
There is also an API; internal page https://github.com/1ES-microsoft/opensource-management-portal/blob/trunk/docs/microsoft.api.md and general info on the link apis https://github.com/1ES-microsoft/opensource-management-portal/blob/trunk/docs/api.md
 
for most, kusto may be sufficient
